title: Tyrannical Management in the Dallas Office
pros: Good pay and benefits package.

title: Formerly great company
pros: Several experienced team leaders (legal, accounting)
cons: Former CEO and CFO led the company on a foolish merger that cost dozens of people their jobs. Both of them eventually got fired for driving a formerly great company into the ditch. Bad balance sheet, bad direction, bad culture.

title: Great company
pros: Good incentives and great management.
cons: Some turnover is possible depending on the role.

title: Great people working hard
pros: Collegial environment, high expectations of employees, people want to do good work, feel like I'm contributing to healthcare by helping physicians and patients
cons: Sometimes micro-managed...I like having high expectations but sometimes it's very stressful.

title: Job for Office Experience or Looking to Move into Property Management
pros: My internal team is very supportive and kind. There are repetitive everyday tasks, but not every day is the same. Always a new project to work on. You can work at your own pace as long as you can get things done by the deadline. You will learn new things daily, especially about property management and equipment. Pretty chill for a temporary job. I am told there are a lot of opportunities to move up. There are companywide fitness challenges and Chair Yoga on Thursdays to try and build community, as well as holiday dinners with staff.
cons: You do not have access to everyone in the company. There is a chain of command you have to go through in order to get certain things done/answer questions. The company had a merge in 2023, and it has been very chaotic since. Lots of issues with rent statements and general system issues. They will throw things at you last minute and throw all the things property managers don't have time for at you. That's how it is being an admin assistant anywhere though. I don't think the wage is fair for the workload. I was told on interview that 60% of my time will be on the phone, but realistically it's more 25% or less. Majority of my time is spent looking at 3 monitors in an office with little interaction. Anyone outside of your office probably does not care about you. You are at the bottom of the ladder. They laid off 40 people at the end of 2023.

title: Look elsewhere
pros: Any reviews which state hiw great this company is were either written by HR themselves or one of the employees who has been there for 20 years. Those employees are a clique and will never leave or be let go. The rest of you are expendable.
cons: Where to start. First, this company has employees who were there before the merger and they are the only ones who matter. If you are not one of them you will have nothing but problems. Upper management shoot first and ask questions later. They take anything their friends say to be fact and do not ask you directly. You are always having to look over your shoulder. The back stabbing is real here. HR does not care about you so don't think you can go to them, you can't. Their system are as antiquated as I have ever seen. You are literally in 1992 when it comes to the companies procedures. The amount of paperwork is ridiculous and completely unnecessary. There is zero money for your properties due to the waste in money on unnecessary procedures and staff. Complaints are ignored and then used against you. Truly makes no difference to me but if you really came here for advise.... RUN.

title: Ok to work at.
pros: The people that you work with.
cons: The ridiculous work load and expectations on deadlines. Pay is below industry. Accounting processes are cumbersome.

title: Heavy workload

title: Growing and getting better
pros: Teamwork is the backbone of everything at Healthcare Realty. Engineers , managers and leasing people work together to make things great at the properties. It's been a big improvement to allow flexible work schedules for employees. There is good communication about our goals and I like volunteering with people in my group. I also like ample oportunities to meet people across the country virtually and in person.
cons: Difference in benefits between HTA and HR

title: Work + deadlines = poor work life balance
pros: They focus on deliver a good job and everybody has been so professional.
cons: Long hours on month end close. They tell you not to work late but a lot of work for the deadlines.

title: Micro-Managing at it’s Finest
pros: Great team that understood the toxic environment we worked in. However, they made excuses for a lot of the behavior seen from upper management as if these things were normal.
cons: Lack of trust in employees with experience. Zero training. Lack of experience in asset managers and directors other than with the company itself. The merger gained buildings in horrible shape with little understanding of just how much time needed to be put into them to repair. More focus on corporate appearance than concern for functional ability. No work life balance if you genuinely care about your team and tenants.

title: Good company overall
pros: Very structured and management has been there over 10 years. Time off and benefits are great - 10 vacation and 8 sick to start out. There's a stock purchase program and they contribute to a HSA account each year for you, plus match 401k. You can learn a lot as they make you do everything.
cons: Work can get overloaded if you show competency. There are 9 staff all paid the same, but the folios are imbalanced. Management has been around a while and are very passive. Very political workplace, lots of lifers that have been with the company a while. Little promotion opportunity, if any.

title: Up to date, if the date is 1985
pros: Good people, vacation/sick days started immediately, opportunity to buy in to stock, small tuition remission potential
cons: Lousy and expensive health plan options, cheap upper management, obsolete software, and they continually confirm that they don't care about employees - they care about shareholders first, upper management second, and employees get the scraps. All decisions across the country are made with Nashville, Tennessee values - they don't seem to understand standards of living in their other markets.

title: HRT? Can it continue to balance Wall Street expectations with a true lack of real estate acumen?
pros: Good company to work for. Stock options, creative thinking, forward approach to healthcare real estate. Great analytical capabilities and good marketing.
cons: Public traded company....sometimes the "street" dictates too much of what should happen rather that normal real estate principles. Company needs more real estate expertise rather than MBA thinking.

title: Terrible work/life balace
pros: Not a lot of pros here. I've never worked for someone so incompetent. She had no idea how to do the tasks I was assigned to do, so how could I ask for help?
cons: Lots of weekend work here as there are not enough staff to get the job done. The PTO policy is pretty bad. 2 weeks may have been standard in 1955, but most places offer at least 3. It's also really strange culturally. You can hear a pin drop in that office. It's like a library. Everyone is just trying to get their work done.

title: Absolutely love working here!!
pros: I have been working at Healthcare Realty for almost 3 years now. From day 1, everyone was extremely friendly and welcoming. I came to this job with little to no accounting experience and have gained a wealth of knowledge. This job gives you the opportunity to challenge yourself in different aspects of accounting. The management team is not only helpful, but appreciates you as a member of the team. I could not imagine a better company to work for!
cons: Cannot think of any disadvantages

title: Enjoyed Working There
pros: I had a great boss. Was able to have some autonomy to learn my job and take the lead to help others and train new employees. 401k has a reasonable match.
cons: Overlooked salary ranges or pay bands being transparent results in new hires being paid more than experienced workers. Medical insurance is expensive and there is only one carrier to choose from.

title: Great company! I love it here!
pros: Everyone here is very friendly and helpful. The staff accountant position is full cycle accounting which helped teach me all aspects of accounting. The management team really cares about the employees and strive to provide us a good work / life balance. There is opportunity for growth and learning and the managers are good "teachers". The work space is nice, free covered parking garage, and the building is easy to get to.
cons: I can't really think of one.

title: Sorry to go
pros: Great benefits with the healthcare etc... I had to quit due to moving and I hated to leave. Everyone was great to work with. There are a few negative people but you have that everywhere. All in all a great company to work for. I wish IT was as responsive with my new employer.
cons: Dress code, I think this could be more casual rather than so stuffy.

title: Good culture, unstable growth
pros: Hiring is done very carefully, everyone who works there is very friendly and get along well. Benefits are good for the private sector. Job stability being in the real estate market.
cons: Company policy and systems are pretty outdated, feels like you're fighting yourself a lot of the time. Also, the company is focused on expanding so quickly without increasing their staffing, it is pushing their employees to their limits.

title: Why reinvent the wheel
pros: Great benefits with vacation, sick and medical/dental. Pay is okay but incentives, bonuses, commission wouldve been nice.
cons: CITRIX system was frustrating and can't get any work done or be productive because of it. Upper management needs reconstruction. Don't fix whats not broken, dont reinvent the wheel!

title: I'm Sorry to My Replacement - I should have written this a year ago
pros: Offers a reasonable average salary - but will still openly lie during negotiations.
cons: This office neglected to take adequate measures to address the pandemic, and then attempted to penalize employees for following health measures which "imposed a hardship on the office". That's what employees were told for QUARANTINING (and still working remotely) during a deadly pandemic. Just look at the way they respond to all the negative reviews on these sites. That's exactly what happens if you have issues in the office too. Aside from that : -You will have no peers. Your leadership will likely be major micromanager and bullies or corporate focused and uninterested in addressing office dynamics, and will often resort to gaslighting keep you in line. -You will get *minimal* training so they has lots of excuses to step in and micromanage. -They will tell you that they are open to collaborating and to your input, this is a lie -When you attempt to address how the management situation has impacted your work performance and personal mental health, you'll likely be met with literal tears. If you do not understand the incredibly serious implications of white women responding with tears to a Black man's legitimate concerns for his safety....then this message is not for you. -After several months, previous complaints of bullying and unfair treatment were discovered as well. -They will take advantage of most people's *need* to be employed and explicitly tell you to tolerate abuse for the sake of a promotion. This is also a lie - there's such little room for growth, your promotion is completely dependent on someone else leaving the company. -The corporate policies are also archaic but you can look at other reviews for those details.

title: Racist Portfolio Manager - Hawaii
pros: Great company overall. They are very helpful to your needs. Positive.
cons: Stressful and hostile environment, Completely terrible and useless management. Constant turnover. Hard to build relationships due to bad reputation.

title: Dallas location is the worse place to work.
pros: The company has good benefits
cons: The managers in certain locations like the Dallas office make the company look bad.

title: A great place to work
pros: So much of the employee experience is the people you work with, and the people at Healthcare Realty are smart, creative, thoughtful, and focused. There's an easy-going and supportive corporate culture, with plenty of opportunities for employees to have a voice. Management is very accessible and there are strong opportunities for career growth.
cons: I can't think of any Cons.

title: Love this job!
pros: Welcoming co-workers, portfolio manager is very genuine , nurturing, personable and very knowledgeable about the diverse culture in Hawaii, pay is competitive, promotes professional growth without hindering personal growth, good parking.
cons: Family plan medical is outrageously expensive. UHA is not the best medical insurance provider. Other than that...there are really no cons.

title: Poor treatment of employees
pros: I cannot speak to any pros at this company.
cons: We were acquired by Healthcare Realty who said it was a true acquisition that would make the company stronger—I believed their empty words. Their actions showed they had no interest in getting to know the people at Healthcare Realty and they just fired employees regardless of skill set and experience. Extremely disappointing and if they can treat current employees this way they will treat any employee in such a manner. Run—do not walk—away from this company!

title: Great place to work, people are friendly
pros: Great work/life balance , health benefits, fast paced learning environment.
cons: Dress code needs to change it is 2019. More up to date working schedule, ie..working remotely on occasion.

title: Happy to be here
pros: Local management actually cares about you as people. There is a lot more flexibility than at other places. The work is challenging and never the same day to day.
cons: As with any REIT it is hard to get approval to add more positions. With corporate office in Nashville, Seattle prices are always a sticker shock.

title: Great Company with Great People
pros: Great promotion opportunities within the company. Great experience can be gained dealing with the many facets of corporate accounting. Great Job!
cons: My only complaint, isn't really a complaint just a suggestion, Casual Fridays would be awesome.

title: Good place to start
pros: When you work with a good team, good outcome fallows. It took some time to build a team and it works.
cons: salary is not so good. little micromanagement benefits are mediocre

title: Growth, culture, opportunities

title: It's not good or not bad, take that as you will.
